38869878.review: Shotgun Legend closely imitates the original Legend of Zelda, and you already know what that is, so let's talk about the shotgun. What makes TLoZ's combat distinct from its successors is the combination of a short sword and grid-locked movement. Fights are a unique kind of scramble for position as Link tries to get right up to the enemy to line up hits, without getting into a vulnerable position himself. Swapping the sword for a shotgun is an effective twist on the design that gives Shotgun Legend its own feel despite how it follows Nintendo's design in other places. Because of the gun's wide spread, you still need to get in close to deal the most damage, but the ability to deal decreasing damage at increasing range allows a lot more flexibility in how enemies and encounters can be designed. Shotgun Legend fully exploits that flexibility with some of the more deviously challenging room layouts I've seen in this genre. It's gaming comfort food, but has enough distinct ideas to be worth checking out.

38642390.review:
An excellent old-school action-adventure in the vein of the original Zelda.  

You have your primary weapon - the titular shotgun, and find a number of secondary weapons and passive equipment along the way.  While the shotgun's range isn't too bad, it has a pretty large spread so you want to be relatively close to your target for maximum damage.  1-2 close up shotgun blasts will take care of most normal monsters, or you can keep picking away at the enemies' invisible healthbars from the relative safety a few meters grant.  Most of the secondary weapons require ammo, that randomly drops from enemies, and can also be bought from some vendor or replenished for free from the occasional ammo station.  Regaining lost "hearts" (HP) works the same way - loot drops, vendors, health stations.  As you progress, you also find heart container (max health) upgrades, ammo capacity upgrades, and shotgun upgrades (adding additional pellets to the shotgun blast).  You can switch secondary weapons by cycling through them while playing, or from the inventory screen which pauses the game play so you don't get hurt while picking the best weapon for the current situation.

The map is open world, littered with monsters and dungeons.  Plenty of secrets in both the map and the dungeons, most of them blocked off by obstacles that require a weapon or item found in the dungeons, so it's best to note down where you come across the (quite obvious) obstacles so you know where to revisit later.   The monsters respawn after you move a few screens away (not sure how many, maybe 4-5), but the cleared obstacles remain cleared.

The vendor at the starting location has a compass costing 10 coins (drops from monsters).  You should buy it quickly, as it gives your character's relative position on the minimap for both the overmap and the dungeons.  However the actual dungeon rooms/features will not be visible until you find the dungeon's map somewhere inside, and the overmap features will not be visible for quite a while longer.  Again, note taking would be encouraged, though there's no real need to actually draw a square-by-square map of your own like some games pretty much required in ye olden times.

The game controls great with the Xbox 360 pad, so I never tried the keyboard controls.  One thing to keep in mind is that this is [b]not[/b] a twin-stick shooter.  The only direction you can fire your weapon is the one in which your character is facing, and the only way (as far as I know) to face in that direction is to move in that direction, which adds a level of difficulty when trying to blast nearby enemies without colliding with them and losing health.

There is a hardcore mode, where you only get the one life and if you die it's Game Over.   I did not even attempt it, considering how many times I died on my play through.  In non-hardcore mode, if you die, you get sent back to the save point.  There is only the one save slot, but that never presented much of a problem to me.  Save points are placed at all dungeon entrances/exits, health & ammo stations, some in-dungeon transitions, and whenever you find an item/upgrade.   If the save is made when your health is too low, reloading it will bump you up to 3 HP or about half your max HP, whichever's greater. 

I had a lot of fun in then 5.5 hours or so that it took me to complete the game.  I did miss one passive item and a few ammo upgrades along the way, hunting them down without a guide would probably take another hour or two, and I'm not enough of a completionist to do that.

Honestly, I'm not sure why Shotgun Legend still in Early Access - I played it from the beginning to end without encountering any bugs.

38608881.review:
This is the first "Early Access" game that I've purchased, and I had some reservations about doing so.  "Early Access" to me indicates buggy and/or unfinished games, that I would basically be paying to be a playtester for.  I can gladly say that this is not the case with Shotgun Legend, and the game is fully completed, and I haven't encountered any bugs during the four hours that I've played the game.  That being said, on to the review of the gameplay:

Let's start by getting the obvious out of the way.  This game is "heavily influenced" by the original Legend of Zelda, to say the least.  That being said, it manages to do something unique with the formula, including some fairly creative powerups and combat strategies.  If you're a fan of the original LoZ, then you should have no problems jumping right into this game.  

While there are many similariites between the two titles, Shotgun Legend offers a new take on the Action-RPG combat by equpping the protagonist with a shotgun instead of a sword.  This allows you to attack enemies from farther away, while decreasing the amount of damage you depending on how far away from the enemy you are.  While this might not seem like a huge deal, it complelety alters the way that you play the game because it is no longer a simple hack-and-slash mechanic that you're dealing with.

The game provides a very basic concept for a story during the intro, but this becomes more fleshed out as you advance and find various notes left around the world that add more to the game's backstory.  All in all, it provides a fairly interesting plot to go along with the basic LoZ exploration concept.

I picked this game up during the Winter Sale for $.49 today, and I honestly didn't have high hopes for it.  Gladly, I have been proven wrong, and have already put 4 hours into playing it.  This is one of those games that you want to keep .playing and advancing in when you start it.  I highly recommend it, and since the game offers trading cards,  you can pick it up for the $.49 sale price, and most likely make back most of, if not all of your money by selling the cards.  

Here's a quick breakdown of the Pros and Cons:

Pros:
- Borrows heavily from the original Legend of Zelda, while paying homage to the same
- Heavy on exploration- lots of secrets to be found, and doesn't hold you hand throughout the whole game
- Replacing the sword with a shotgun offers a unique approach to playing a familiar action-rpg
- Secondary items are creative and help to enhance the different ways in which to play the game
- Despite being an "early access game," offers a complete game, that seems to be free of any major bugs
- Very cheap, especially if you can get it during a sale
- Offers Steam trading cards, which can potentially get you back all or some of the money you spent on it

Cons
- Difficulty spikes with some of the dungeon bosses.  While most are fairly easy to beat after learning their pattern, ther are a couple that really ramp up the difficulty
- As someone with red/green colorblindness, I sometimes got killed because I failed to see a bat that blended into the background, or because I couldn't tell the differece between a normal enemy or its poisonous (green?) counterpart.


All in all I definitely recommend this game, especially to any Legend of Zelda fans out there.  I've played many ROM hacks of the original LoZ, and this game manages to do what most of the don't- introduces something fresh and avoids becomign stale and repetative.

38382746.review:
[b]Shotgun Legend[/b] is a tribute to the Legend of Zelda, but instead of Link, you are Eugene, a shotgun wielding hillbilly. In this retro 2D RPG, you explore an unfamiliar world that is plagued with evil aliens who are trying to resurrect their leader. As a result, the lands are swarming with the undead and other challenges you must face to get back home. Overall, Shotgun Legend is a great example of a retro RPG done well. Exploration is fun and rewarding, dungeons are challenging, and combat is exciting. 

[h1][u]Positive:[/u][/h1]
[list]
[*]Notes are scattered all over the world and provide just enough information for you to figure out what to do next. As such, plenty of exploring is expected and required, but the game isn’t cryptic to the point of frustration. In fact, exploration often rewards you with upgrades. This is a refreshing break from games that hold your hand from start to end. 
[*]Blasting crabs, bats, and skeletons with a shotgun is so satisfying. I also enjoyed the trade-off you have to consider when using a shotgun. The further away you are from your enemies, the safer you are, but you do less/no damage. Whereas if you want to do maximum damage, you must position yourself dangerously close to your foes. Finding the ideal balance is necessary to complete the game, as it is fairly easy to die and somewhat difficult to kill enemies.
[*]You have a good selection of secondary weapons that have different strengths and weaknesses. This becomes especially fun towards the end of the game, where you can adjust your playstyle and weapon choices depending on the enemies or map design. [spoiler]The banjo made me crack up.[/spoiler]
[*]All the hidden rooms and locations can be found if you pay enough attention. The cracks in the stones/walls are always clear, and walkable paths, through trees for example, are of a different colour. 
[*]At first I didn’t like that Cedric’s shotgun was placed as a secondary item instead of replacing and strengthening your main shotgun. However, once I started dual wielding shotguns, I felt like a madman on steroids. Very nice. 
[/list]

[h1][u]Negative:[/u][/h1]
[list]
[*]Very few music tracks; there were only 2 or 3 different tracks, as far as I could tell. As a result, it gave the game an unnecessarily tedious feel. I ended up turning the music off and listening to other songs while playing. I think the addition of tracks that are specific to each area/dungeon would vastly improve the playability of Shotgun Legend.
[*]In most Legend of Zelda games, the boss at the end of the dungeon requires you to use your newly acquired item to defeat it. This is not the case in Shotgun Legend. I don’t think any boss requires you to use anything besides your shotgun. While I don’t think this is a huge flaw, I would have liked if this was incorporated (perhaps in the next Shotgun Legend game?). 
[*]I think it would be nice if the keys could be remapped, especially for those playing with a keyboard. It would also be great if the player could assign the secondary weapons to specific keys to avoid having to scroll through each item individually.
[*]The order in which you enter/complete dungeons doesn’t seem to matter much. I didn’t really pay attention to which dungeon I was in and just went with a first-find-first-go approach. There was one situation where I needed the shield generator but didn’t have it yet because I went to the wrong dungeon. I managed to progress by simply tanking shots. I think it would be good to somehow enforce a certain dungeon completing order. 
[/list]

[h1][u]Conslusion:[/u][/h1]
[h1]★★★★☆ Surprisingly great[/h1]

If I were browsing the Steam store, it is very likely that I wouldn’t have taken a second look at Shotgun Legend. Luckily, this game was recommended to me, so I gave it a try. I’m happy to say that I was not disappointed in the slightest. Shotgun Legend was a thoroughly enjoyable experience, so it would have been a tragedy if I simply chose to ignore it. As a Steam community I think it’s important to support the small indie developers that really care about making great games. Without these pioneers we wouldn’t have the opportunity to play such unique titles. Jonathan Tindell did (and is still updating/fixing the game) an excellent job with this game, so I urge you to put your scepticism to the side and try Shotgun Legend.

Imagine The Legend of Zelda do Nintendinho. Agora, tire toda a rica ambientação e história de Hyrule, e substitua por um prólogo sem pé nem cabeça onde um cara estava procurando uma roda para seu carro num ferro velho, e foi abduzido por alienígenas e levado para uma ilha bizarra, e peças da roda que ele queria foram espalhadas pelo mundo, lotado de mortos-vivos. E pra que uma espada, se uma escopeta faz o trabalho melhor?

Shotgun Legend é um jogo bem retrô em muitos aspectos, utilizando a visão top-down clássica, a jogabilidade meio travada, e o mínimo de botões. O combate não é difícil, mas é dificultado pela limitação na mobilidade do personagem, que também só pode atirar no sentido em que anda - como nos jogos antigos. Tudo fica mais difícil ainda pela escopeta dar mais dano a inimigos mais próximos, então você é incentivado a se colar em risco para matar inimigos rapidamente.

Fora isso, se você morrer (e acredite, você vai morrer), terá que aguentar a tela de Game Over para te desmoralizar, e depois dar "Continue" e voltar do ultimo save automático, que ocorre entre certas telas com frequência. Ao morrer e continuar, todos os inimigos respawnam no mundo, ou seja, mais emoção e chance de morrer!

O jogo contém vários elementos do clássico também, onde você entrará em dungeons, procurará chaves, adquirirá itens que irão permitir o acesso de novas áreas e salas anteriormente inacessíveis, e ao final da dungeon enfrentará um chefe, que te dará uma vida extra, e um pedaço da tão sonhada roda.

Essa é a proposta básica do jogo, colocada de forma bem crua, com sons desagradáveis, música simples, e uma roupagem bem cafona - mas divertida!

Fora isso, a primeira habilidade que você pega é a skill Doppelganger, que ao ser usada, irá habilitar/desabilitar o cooperativo local, portanto você pode trazer um clone seu para a aventura em coop para 2 jogadores, tendo ambos uma mesma vida compartilhada!

Using a shotgun to fight definitely takes some practice because of the random spread and how it doesn't knock enemies away like swords do in other games.  However the shotgun mechanic creates a good risk/reward situation everytime you engage an enemy.  Another good thing to see is that the NPCs will defend themselves if you attack them.  And it will hurt when they fight back.

When I have seen problems with the game, the developer was quick to fix any issues like crashes or problem areas.  For example I commented that when you get a rim fragment it shouldn't teleport you to the entrance of the dungeon becuase there might still be things in the place you need to collect.  So he fixed it almost the next day.

I know this review seems to be scatter brained but that's probably becuase I just need to improve my writing.

Some improvements I recommend if the developer has time and resources to do them.
[list]
[*]-Most dungeons could use a few more updates to make them harder to solve.  Not by adding more enemies but forcing the player to think more about how to get through them instead of the linear setup for most underground areas.
[*]-Leave more clues in the world about the background story.  It's an action game and story isn't critical but it can add more appeal if you have time.
[*]-Add more hidden areas in the overworld.  Not necessarily for more equipment (unless you want to) but maybe some collectibles you can get an achievement for.

[/list]

I really recommend this game.

I was a little wary of all of the positive reviews at first, but let me say that this is a game that really does grow on you.

When I first kicked-off the game I had a basic knowledge of the NES Legend of Zelda games, but I found myself dying a fair bit, more than I expected. And it wasn't until I persisted and got to the first dungeon (after having died a fair bit in the Level 4 dungeon without realising it!) - that I began to understand what the game was about.

Suffice it to say, that as a tribute, this does indeed check all the right boxes. It's still in early access as I write this, but I was lucky enough to be able to talk to the developer as I was playing, and provided a little feedback, and he is adamant that he takes all feedback into consideration, which to me is already a win.

I have currently gotten to the point where I am in the final dungeon, which in its present state is only three rooms, but this is actively being worked-on, and I am told will be done fairly soon, at which point I would love to come back and try again.

All of this said, there are a couple of points I hope are addressed in the near future:

- Smart Bomb / Wave Cannon sound effects are a lot louder than expected, and can put folks off, I have found.
- When I originally walked through the evil forest to get to what I thought was the next dungeon, I found I was mistaken, and getting back was a nightmare, as every time I died it reset me back to that dungeon. Cue 20 minutes of me desperately trying to make it out alive..! Not sure whether I should just suck that one up though...
- Final Dungeon location is not immediately obvious, nor was the hint to its location (which I never found, but was told about)
- Grid-based movement is a little cumbersome when fighting enemies in tight corners, but not sure how you could get around this.
- Some respawn locations are right on top of enemies, so when you restart with three hearts, unless you are moving and shooting immediately, you often lose some health.

Other than that, a very enjoyable title, and one I fully intend on playing again when it has been finished!

Ante todo agradecer a Jonathan Tindell y a Wastebasket Games por adelantarme una KEY del juego que se estrena el próximo jueves día 1.
 
¿Os imagináis si link en el primer Legend of Zelda para NES en lugar de la clásica espada llevara una escopeta recortada?............. Pues esta es la respuesta ;)
 
Shotgun Legend nos sitúa frente a un homenaje en toda regla al clásico juego de NES, no en vano así se promociona el mismo, y la verdad es que razón no le falta.
 
Tomamos el control de nuestro personaje recortada en mano, y le disparamos a todo bicho que se nos cruce en el camino, aunque eso sí, pese a la recortada el juego es difícil. Los enemigos son bastante resistentes, y se ha limitado la visibilidad en las mazmorras, siendo más complejo localizar a los enemigos y las trampas en cada habitación, por lo que moriremos irremediablemente una y otra vez hasta aprendernos las habitaciones de memoria, como en los viejos tiempos.
 
Gráficamente se muestra como un clásico de 8 bits, sin mucho que achacar en este aspecto, tiene su gracia la animación de los cartuchos tras cada disparo.
 
La música es agradable, y los efectos de sonido están bien, sobre todo la contundencia de la recortada al disparar.
 
El control (una vez configurado) es bastante sencillo y no requiere de muchos botones o combinaciones extrañas. Y es que el control es su principal talón de aquiles, ya que aunque se indica “COMPATIBILIDAD TOTAL CON CONTROLADOR”, prácticamente me he pasado medio video ingeniandomelas para hacerlo funcionar. Llama mucho la atención que mientras en los menus funciona correctamente, en el juego no funciona nada, y se trata de una mando con los drivers del de xbox 360, con el que prácticamente todos los juegos funcionan perfectamente.
También se echa en falta la posibilidad de configurar la disposición de los botones desde el juego, ya que el estándar por defecto en teclado usa las flechas para moverse, y los botones A,Z,S,X, convirtiéndose en una configuración muy muy rara, casi como la que diseñe yo mismo para Destiny Emeralds XD
 
Solo me queda agradecer de nuevo por la KEY, y animaros a que lo probéis en Steam el próximo día 1 de Junio.

32102179.review:
ベータ版0.8.6をプレイ

[h1]良い点[/h1]

・トラックのリムをジャンクヤードで探していたら何時の間にか異世界へ飛ばされたオッちゃんが主役のFC版「ゼルダの伝説」にインスパイアされた見下ろし型視点の2Dアクションゲーム。オッちゃんは何故がショットガンを持った状態で開始する。きっと常に持ち歩いているのだろう。ストーリーがぷっとんでいるのも長所だと思うんだ。

・システム周りはシンプルで、HP（ハート）が初期は五個あり、メインウェポンとサブウェポンを使い分けつつプレイしていく。他にも攻略に役立つアイテムも。ハートの最大値上昇用のアイテムやサブウェポンはダンジョン等で入手可能。初期のお店で売っているキャンドルは絶対に買おう。いや、マジで。

・自由度が高く序盤で行ける場所が多い。特定のアイテムを所持していた方が攻略が簡単になるが、持っていなくても攻略可能な場所が多いように感じた。

・マップ上にダンジョンが存在していて、中に入るとダンジョンの難易度がレベルで表示されるので、難しいと思ったら後回しにすることも可能。初回プレイ時は気付かなかったので、レベル4のダンジョンを攻略した後にレベル1を攻略したのは私です。難しいわけや。

・初期から所持しているショットガン以外にもサブウェポンや攻略に使用するアイテムが存在している。いくつかのサブウェポンはダンジョンの仕掛けを起動させるのに使用することも。

・ダンジョンやマップ等で特定のアイテムを入手することで武器は強化可能。初期から所持しているショットガンなら、一撃ごとの散弾の数が上がるので単純に攻撃力が上がり使い勝手が良くなる。このおかげで初期装備がゲーム終盤で使い物にならなくなるということが無い。他のサブウェポン等はゼル伝よろしく弾薬の最大所持数がアップする。

[h1]悪い点[/h1]

個人的には特に無いがあえて気になった点を二つほど。

・自由度が高いこともあり、初回プレイ時にはどこから攻略を始めていいかわからない可能性もある。迷うのも楽しみの一つではあるが人にもよるかと。

・慣れるまではショットガンを何処から撃てば敵に当たるのかわかりづらい。序盤は反撃を受けてしまう事が多かった。慣れてくると遠くから当てられるし、逆に近づいて高ダメージ叩きだすことができるので完全に慣れの問題。

[h1]総評[/h1]

ここまでに何度も「ＦＣ版ゼル伝」を引き合いに出しているが、「ゼルダの伝説」に影響を受けて開発をされただけはあり、制作陣の「愛」を感じる出来になっているので好きな方は購入して損はないだろう。ちょっとした謎解きなどもある。

逆にＳＦＣ版「ゼルダの伝説」に似ていると思って購入を検討している方は気を付けてほしい。肩透かしを食らうかも。
ちなみにこのレビューを書いている時点ではまだ試していないが主人公のドッペルゲンガーを召喚して協力プレイ（2Ｐ）も可能とのこと。その場合はHP(ハート)はプレイヤー間でシェアされる。友達とプレイするとまた違った楽しみがありそうだ。

プレイ動画をアップしているので、気になった方は[u][url=https://youtu.be/aD7JWW9r8aw]こちら[/url][/u]を参考までにどうぞ。

Do you like Zelda, and games similar to Zelda? If so, I think you'll be mostly pleased with Shotgun Legend as it clearly pays homage to the original Legend of Zelda on the NES - albeit with some changes to suit the more gun-based weaponry system.

The main cons that I can think of - if I'm being purely nitpicky is that the shotgun often feels like it doesn't have a set damage due to the spread of the pellets. Sometimes you'll one shot kill an enemy. Another time the same enemy will take four shots because the crab keeps piroetting out of the way of your shots while you're low on health and don't really want to tempt fate by running up and shooting him directly in the face. Movement also felt a little floaty at times - it doesn't feel like it has weight to each step like Zelda does. 

Still if you're coming into this for a Zelda-like experience you're gonna find items. You're gonna fight bosses at the end of a dungeon and get a heart container. There's a vague plot in the background that you can almost completely ignore if you're more worried about just shooting things. Overall I'd recommend it for the intended audience.

At the time of this review I completed four dungeons - and since the game asks you to review the game at the end of dungeon three I figured I'd do it ... even if putting a declaration of wanting steam reviews in the game itself is a bit too mobile game-esq for my tastes.

38977253.review:
《猎枪传说》是对FC上的《塞尔达传说》的一款致敬作，一进入游戏你就能从各种地方找到《塞尔达传说》的影子——左上方的小地图、A键主武器B键（X键）副武器、半颗半颗扣心的血条，还有最重要的迷宫探索部分。游戏的主要玩法也如出一辙，在大地图上获取金钱、升级与小部分关键道具并寻找迷宫，在迷宫中获取关键道具以前往新地点、打败boss、收集通关道具以前往最终boss处。可以说《猎枪传说》在外形与游戏机制上对《塞尔达传说》的还原是很成功的。
那么《猎枪传说》是对《塞尔达传说》单纯的借鉴与模仿吗？事实上在画面的提升之外它也有一些新东西。比如游戏标题中的猎枪，作为主武器的它有着距离敌人越近伤害便越高、无法快速连续射击的特性，这就使游戏的战斗节奏与《塞尔达传说》略有不同了；再比如双人模式，在游戏初期就能得到一个叫“二重身”的道具，持有这个道具时只要在另一个控制器上（我是用键盘和手柄，不知道其他情况下是怎样的）按下开始键便可两个人同屏合作进行游戏（此时HP是共用的），无疑是加强了游戏的趣味性与战斗的策略性。不过《猎枪传说》现阶段还是没有跳脱出《塞尔达传说》的游戏模式，希望游戏中有什么重大创新与特色的玩家可能要失望了。
此外，这款游戏也有一些缺点：BGM十分单调，听得头疼；数量不多的隐藏要素（也可能是我智商太低找不到），所有隐藏区域都有明显提示，不太有惊喜感；很平淡的地图设计，基本就是主路上加上一两条走到头后只能原路返回的岔路，要么就是不小心走进去就得绕一大圈回来的单向门，偶尔再来一两个传送门；道具的用途太过单一，游戏中后期除了开机关外基本全程双持猎枪，其他副武器的特点没有凸显出来；键盘的键位略微有点奇怪，习惯了《洞窟物语》那种AS切换ZX使用的操作方式的话会非常难受，但又没办法改键位等等。但考虑到这款游戏还在抢先体验阶段，这些问题今后可能会有改进。
总的来说，这款游戏还是很有趣的，流程也不长，难度也不是很高，五到六个小时就能通关，对FC《塞尔达传说》各方面的还原也很好，如果你是塞尔达系列的忠实玩家不妨一试，新玩家也可从中略微窥见塞尔达传说的魅力所在。对于成就党来说，目前全成就还是很容易的，包括收集全部道具和升级、通关。如果你是想挑战自我，也可以试试游戏提供的取消自动存档，要求一命通关的硬核模式。诚然这不是一款十分优秀的作品，但也能让玩家度过几小时愉快的时光了。（本评测基于v0.9.10版本）
